ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about security theory, security dilemmas in North Africa and the Middle East, considering security on various levels, and developed a depth of knowledge in security-related case studies (Israel-Palestine, ISIS, Syrian crisis, Iranian nuclear threat, Western Sahara, jihadi groups in the Sahel, North African security sector reform, the state as a threat to security, migrant insecurity, gender insecurity, and minority insecurity). I developed my skills in reading academic papers in social science: critiquing texts, distilling the most important points into a sentence or two, and understanding complex arguments and analyses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: strong grounding in texts, reading selection - nearly all of the readings were fascinating, insightful, and connected to each other in ways that made sense for the flow of the course, class discussions

Weaknesses: the assignments could have been laid out more clearly in the syllabus; I ended up getting a much better idea of what I was supposed to do from going to office hours, but it would have been helpful to have examples or more detailed descriptions for the reviews, final paper, and final project

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES. This was far and away my favorite class I took this semester; I did all of the readings thoroughly, took detailed notes, participated a lot in our class discussions, and spent a long time doing assignments because the material was so engaging. Professor Messari is brilliant, concise, and skilled at asking critical questions about the texts and having students figure out what the central themes, important takeaways, and difficult questions are. This class is definitely one you have to commit to, but if you do, it will be one of the best you take.
